paragraphs.text: 2015: Will America continue its slow march toward destruction of liberty?
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: A British author, residing in the United States for the past 30 years, created a small firestorm earlier this week with his candid observations that modern- day Americans have been duped by the government into accepting a European- style march toward socialism
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: because we fail to appreciate the rich legacy of personal liberty that is everyone's birthright and is expressly articulated in the Declaration of Independence and guaranteed by the U.S  Constitution
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Os Guinness, the author of more than a dozen books defending traditional Judeo-Christian values and Jeffersonian personal liberty, argued that we should embrace individual liberty and personal dignity and reject the "no givens, no rules, no limits" government we now have
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: He went on to opine that the government today is not the constitutionally restrained protector of personal freedoms the Framers left us
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: but rather has become the wealth-distributing protector of collective interests the Founding Fathers never could have imagined
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Yet the problem is a deep one
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Framers believed in the presumption of liberty
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: which declares that we are free to make personal choices, and the government cannot interfere with our liberties unless we violate the rights of others
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: Stated differently
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the federal government cannot interfere with our personal choices by writing any law it wants
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: it can only regulate behavior or spend money when the Constitution authorizes it to do so
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But for the past 100 years, the federal government has rejected the Madisonian concept that it is limited to the 16 discrete powers the Constitution delegates to it, and has claimed its powers are unlimited, subject only to the express prohibitions in the Constitution
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Even those prohibitions can be gotten around
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: since government lawyers have persuaded federal courts to rule that Congress can spend tax dollars or borrowed money on any projects it wishes, whether authorized by the Constitution or not
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The courts even have authorized Congress to use federal tax dollars to bribe the states into enacting laws that Congress is powerless to enact
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Congress has done so
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Declaration of Independence defines our personal liberties as inalienable aspects of our humanity
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the Constitution prohibits the government from interfering with those liberties-- like thought, speech, press, association, worship, self-defense, travel, privacy, due process, use of money and private property
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: to name a few
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: The teaching of these founding documents is that our liberties are natural-- their source is not the government
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: -- and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: they are personal, not collective
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: We don't need a government permission slip to exercise them
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: we don't need to belong to a group to enjoy them
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: they cannot be taken away by a congressional vote or a presidential signature
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: Even though everyone who works for the government takes an oath to uphold the Declaration and the Constitution
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: very few are consistent with what they have sworn to do
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We know that because on the transcendental issues of our day -- life, liberty, war and debt -- the leadership of both political parties and the behavior of all modern presidents have revealed a steadfast willingness to write any law and regulate any behavior or permit any evil
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: , whether authorized by the Constitution or not.
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Take life
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: Abortion is the most deadly force in America today
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Abortions lawfully kill a baby a minute
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: that's 1.1 million babies a year and 45,000,000 killed since the Supreme Court issued its Roe v  Wade decision in 1973
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A simple one-line statute --"The fetus in the womb is a legal person"-- could have been enacted by a simple majority vote in Congress and signed into law by any of our so-called pro-life presidents, thus stopping the slaughter
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It never happened
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: Take liberty
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: Both parties support the Patriot Act and the secret FISA apparatus
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which together invade privacy, infringe upon free speech, permit federal agents to write their own search warrants and allow domestic spying on all of us all the time
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This demonstrates that our political leaders do not believe that our rights are inalienable, but can be interfered with and regulated by them
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They have written laws that literally permit federal agents to do the very acts the Constitution was written to prohibit
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Take the lethal combination of war and debt
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: Both parties support perpetual war and perpetual debt
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The leadership of both parties has permitted every modern president to kill whomever he pleases in foreign countries without lawful declarations of war and to do so by going into a $17 trillion hole of debt, with no end in sight
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Today, 20 cents of every tax dollar collected goes to interest on pre-existing government debt
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Today's taxpayers are still paying interest on the $30 billion Woodrow Wilson borrowed to finance World War I in 1917
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The British author is correct
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Unless we have a radical change in the direction of government -- its size, cost, focus, intrusiveness and rejection of first principles -- and unless we elect people to the government who truly believe the Declaration and the Constitution mean what they say, we will continue our march toward the federal destruction of the presumption of liberty
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It is a slow march, but a steady one
paragraphs.label: assumption
